review.title: A Review: Expert System for Diagnosis of Myocardial Infarction
review.abstract: A computer Program Capable of performing at a human-expert level in a narrow problem domain area is called an expert system. Management of uncertainty is an intrinsically important issue in the design of expert systems because much of the information in the knowledge base of a typical expert system is imprecise, incomplete or not totally reliable. In this paper, the author present s the review of past work that has been carried out by various researchers based on development of expert systems for the diagnosis of cardiac disease

sections.text: (ISSN 2250-2459, Volume 2, Issue 1, January 2012) In this paper, biomedical, agricultural and automotive fields come under the diagnosis and troubleshooting with ES, which performs all the necessary data manipulation, as a human expert would do. Other areas use different techniques such as fuzzy logic, rule-based thinking, CLIPS, etc., which actually fall within the decision and planning area of ES. No matter in which business area one is engaged, ES can meet the need for higher productivity and reliability of decisions. Anyone can find an application potential in the field of ESs. Expert systems can actually help create opportunities for new areas of work. In order to be considered useful and acceptable, ESs must be able to explain their knowledge of the area and the reasoning processes they use to produce results and recommendations. sections.heading: Mohammed Aslam.C, SatyaNarayana.D, Padma Priya.K :
sections.text: (International Journal of Computer Applications in Engineering Sciences [VOL I, ISSUE IV, DECEMBER 2011]) This paper proposes a novel fuzzy inference system and mathematical-morphological algorithms for segmentation of blood vessels, showing that the algorithm is more efficient at segmenting angiogram images and noise suppression than other methods, such as the clever method.

sections.heading: Djam, and Y.H. Kimbi: (volume 12. Number 1. May 2011 (Spring))
sections.text: In this paper, systolic blood pressure, diastolic blood pressure, age and body mass index (BMI) were used as input parameters for the Fuzzy Expert System, and hypertension risk was the starting parameter; the resulting hypertension risk was based on fuzzy rules developed for the Expert System; entry user membership functions are low, normal, high, and very high for blood pressure; the output membership functions are mild, moderate, and severe; the defusioning method used in this paper is the root sum square; the expert system is designed based on clinical observations, medical diagnosis, and expert knowledge; and the Expert System provides a web-based user interface designed using PHP as the scripting language with MySQL Relation Database on Apache Sever on Windows operating system; the logical results were selected using script and HTML system definition and HTML system.

sections.heading: Mir Anamul Hasan, Khaja Md. Sher-E-Alam and Ahsan Raja Chowdhury (JOURNAL OF COMPUTING, VOLUME 2, ISSUE 6,
sections.text: JUNE 2010, ISSN2151-9617) Diagnosing human diseases is a complicated process and requires a high level of expertise, and any attempt to develop a web-based expert system to diagnose human diseases must overcome various difficulties. This paper describes a project to develop a web-based fuzzy expert system to diagnose human diseases. Nowadays, fuzzy systems are successfully used in an increasing number of applications; they use linguistic rules to describe systems. This research project focuses on researching and developing a web-based clinical tool to improve the quality of the exchange of health information between physicians and patients. Practitioners can also use this web-based tool to confirm diagnoses, and the proposed system will be tested against various scenarios to evaluate its performance.

sections.heading: Shaikh Abdul Hannan, V. D. Bhagile, R. R. Manza,, R. J. Ramteke :
sections.text: (Vol. 02, No. 06, 2010, 2150-2159) In this paper, approximately 300 patient information is collected from Sahara Hospital under the supervision of Dr. Abdul Jabbar, (MD Medicine) Sahara Hospital, Roshan Gate, Aurangabad. The information collected is encoded, normalized, and fed into 13 different Excel subsheets. All patient data is trained using SVM and FFBP. Approximately 50 samples have been tested using these two techniques. If the larger dataset is used for training, the NN model provides more robust results. The analysis model using SVM and FFBPof ANN provides less appropriate results for medical prescribing heart disease. However, there are several techniques that can improve the speed and performance of the reverse propagation algorithm, weight initialization, the use of dynamics, and the adaptive learning rate.

sections.heading: Ali.Adeli, Mehdi.Neshat: (IMECS , March 17-2010 Hong Kong)
sections.text: The designed system is based on the database of the V.A. Medical Center, Long Beach and Cleveland Clinic Foundation. The system has 13 input fields and one output field. Input fields are chest pain type, blood pressure, cholesterol, dormant blood sugar, maximum heart rate, resting electrocardiography (ECG), exercise, old peak (ST depression caused by exercise in relation to resting), thallium scan, sex and age. The output field refers to the presence of heart disease in the patient. It is integer from 0 (no presence) to 4 (differentiation of presence (values 1, 2, 3, 4)). This system uses the Mamdani Inference Method. The results of the designed system are compared with the data in a database and the observed results of the designed system are 94% correct. The system was designed in the Matlab software. The system can be considered as an alternative.

sections.heading: V.Mahesh, A.Kandaswamy, and R.Venkatesan: (International Journal of Recent Trends in Engineering,
sections.text: Vol 2, No. 3, November 2009), he introduces the development of a web-based telecardiological framework for diagnosing heart patients in rural areas. Rural health centres, a central server and competent cardiologists form the framework. Personal data, clinical information and ECGs obtained from a patient in the rural centre are sent to a central server, which processes the ECG file to extract the lead measurements and waveform data. The expert views the patient's clinical information, lead measurements and ECGwaveforms and delivers his diagnosis for treatment. The server stores the diagnosed results and forwards them to the respective rural centre. The doctor in the rural centre can view the diagnosed results and recommendations from the expert and the treatment.

sections.heading: William J. Long: 1992
sections.text: This paper reports on a formative assessment of the diagnostic capabilities of the Heart Failure Program, which uses a probability network and heuristic hypotheses generator. Using 242 heart cases collected from outpatient summaries at a hospital for tertiary care, we compared the diagnoses of the program with diagnoses collected by cardiologists using the same information available to the program. With some adjustments to the knowledge base, the Heart Failure Program makes appropriate diagnoses about 90% of the time on this training package. Among the main reasons for the inadequate diagnoses of the remaining 10% are inadequate reasoning with time relationships between cause and effect, severity relationships, and independence from acute and chronic diseases.

sections.heading: MARCIN GRABOWSKI, KRZYSZTOF J. FILIPIAK,ROBERT RUDOWSKI1 AND GRZEGORZ OPOLSKI:
sections.text: The aim of the project was to create a computer program expert system to assist the physician in selecting management for patients with acute coronary syndrome. The expert system consists of four modules: knowledge base, database of previous cases, inference engine and explanation module. The knowledge base was created with the support of clinical experts, based on current management standards, guidelines and results of clinical trials in accordance with evidence-based medical rules. Data from new patients is added to the case database. Inference engine integrates two types of reasoning, rule-based and case-based. Computer expert system provides clear and objective answers. Recommendations of an expert system can be reliable. Currently, the system is being tested in clinical practice. Strategies recommended by the system are compared with management applied to patients treated in the cardiology clinic.

sections.heading: G.N.R. Prasad, Dr. A. Vinaya Babu:
sections.text: This paper deals with the need for expert systems in agriculture and the availability of different expert systems in different countries. The need for expert systems for technical information transfer in agriculture can be identified by identifying the problems. The advantages that an expert system can offer better than traditional methods. It has been proven that expert systems in agriculture do much to increase crop production, but most expert systems are in English. By developing an expert system in agriculture in the native language of a farmer, it helps him to know the facts and truths about increasing production. sections.heading: Paul Dorsey, Dulcian :
sections.text: The methodology presented in this paper combines three main aspects: theoretical foundations, practical implementation and workflow organization.The theoretical foundations come from commonKADS, the second generation expert system that approaches the state of the art. Practical experience has been gained through the development of several expert systems in the field of plant production management, which directly influences both the application of the methodology and the organizational structure of the workflow in the laboratory M Sasikumar, S Ramani, S Muthu Raman KSR Anjaneyulu, R Chandrasekar: There are some basic ideas in expert systems that should be understood before implementing expert systems. However, these ideas should only be the springboards to the practical aspects of expert systems technology. In view of this, we have tried to offer in this book a reasonable mix of principles and practical aspects. The book is based around a part-time course on expert systems, the National Expert Systems Management System Course, the focus of which is on the Technology ST in this book.

sections.heading: Vanisree K , yothi Singaraju :
sections.text: His work presents a decision support system for the diagnosis of congenital heart disease that can speed up the diagnostic process, improve the accuracy of the diagnosis and reduce costs without compromising diagnostic performance.The proposed system also reduces the number of diagnostic tests and predicts the disease at an early stage of the disease.Therefore, the current system offers better performance compared to manual diagnosis Romeo Mark A. Mateo, Bobby D. Gerardo and Jaewan Lee This work presents an expert healthcare system (HES) based group collaboration model for implementing QoS and system efficiency through the use of object replicas and effective coordination of the system using the proposed agent manager. The group collaboration model has been discussed for the proposed expert healthcare system. A group of objects or services is managed by the proposed agent manager, where it selects the necessary objects from the replicator server. The global load monitor and load analyzer manage the flow of the replicator to the adaptive flow of the objects.

sections.heading: Rajdeep Borgohain and Sugata Sanyal
sections.text: In this article we discussed the design and implementation of a rules-based expert system for the diagnosis of cerebral palsy, which helps to diagnose cerebral palsy and classify it as mild, moderate or severe. In implementing this system, we took into account the most classic symptoms of cerebral palsy and weighted each symptom according to user feedback. The expert system can make a great contribution to supporting the decision-making process of health professionals and also help parents with children with cerebral palsy to assess their children and take appropriate measures to manage the disease.

sections.heading: Eric J. Horvitz :
sections.text: Pathfinder is an expert system that helps surgical pathologists diagnose lymph node diseases. It is one of a growing number of normative expert systems that use probability and decision theory to acquire, depict, manipulate, and explain uncertain medical knowledge. In this article, we describe Pathfinder and the exploration of paradigms of uncertainty thought stimulated by the development of the program. We discuss limitations of early decision-based methods of thinking under uncertainty and the initial attempts to apply non-decision-theory methods. We then describe experimental and theoretical results that led us to reasoning methods based on probability and decision theory.

sections.heading: Rahime Ceylan , Yüksel Özbay , Bekir Karlik :
sections.text: In this thesis, the new telemedicine system was presented as an automated diagnostic system assisting the practitioner. Furthermore, the T2FCNN was proposed and developed to classify electrocardiographic signals. In the proposed structure, the conventional type 1 memberships for each pattern were extended to type 2. These type 2 memberships were included in the cluster update process. Cluster centers obtained by T2FCM are classified by neural network. The realized T2FCNN structure was compared with the studies in the literature.
